Name: Diphenylmethane diisocyanate   (4,4'-M.D.I.)
Rationale for classification: Category 2 because of "SPECIES: Rat; ENDPOINT: LC50(4hr.; VALUE: 0.369mg/L"(ACGIH 7th, 2001)

Name: 2,2-Dibromo-2-cyanoacetamide
Rationale for classification: Saturated vapor pressure level of this substance (25degC)is 1.18 ppm (0.01 mg/L). Since LC50 value with 0.32 mg/L of the 4-hour inhalation exposure test employing rats (HSDB (2008)) was larger than saturated vapor pressure level, it was classified into Category 2 by applying the dust standard.

Name: Methamidophos
Rationale for classification: Based on the rat LC50 (4 hour inhalation of dust) value of 0.162mg/L (RTECS (2006)).

Name: alpha-cyano-3-phenoxybenzyl N-(2-chloro-alpha,alpha,alpha-trifluoro-p-tolyl)-D-valinate
Rationale for classification: Based on the rat LC50 (inhalation route) value of 0.44mg/L (Agricultural Chemical Registration Data (1988)).

Name: 2-chloro-1-phthalimidoethyl O,O-diethyl phosphorodithioate
Rationale for classification: From rat LC50 = 0.13mg/L of JMPR(Joint Meeting on Pesticide Residures-Monographs&Evaluations)363 (WHO/IPCS, 1976) equivalent to Priority 1, it was set as Category 2.

Name: 2-(Diethylamino)ethyl methacrylate
Rationale for classification: Based on the guinea pig LC50 value of 1,500ppm, calculated from the testing data of guinea pig LC50 (4 hour inhalation of vapour) of 11mg/L (CERI Hazard Data 2001-64 (2002)), exceeded the saturated vapour concentration (140ppm) under a saturated vapour pressure of 0.014kPa (25degC) (HSDB (2006)), the substance was considered as "mist exposure," and  the obtained LC50 was lower than the upper limit value of Category 4 (5mg/L) by more than 2.5 fold.

Name: 5-Chloro-N-{2-[4-(2-ethoxyethyl)-2,3-dimethylphenoxy]ethyl}-6-ethylpyrimidine-4-amine; Pylimidifen
Rationale for classification: Based on the rat LC50 (inhalation route) value of 0.069mg/L (Agricultural Chemical Registration Data (1993)).

Name: Sodium dichromate
Rationale for classification: It was set as category 2 based on rat LC50 = 0.2mg/L (EU-RAR (2005)).

Name: p-Chloroaniline
Rationale for classification: Based on the rat LC50 value of 448ppm, calculated from the testing data of rat LC50 (4-hour inhalation) of 2.34mg/L (MOE Risk Assessment vol. 2 (2003)) exceeded the saturated vapour concentration (20ppm) under a saturated vapour pressure of 2.0kPa (20degC), the substance was classified based on the mist/dust classification.

Name: p-Phenylenediamine
Rationale for classification: Based on the rat LC50 (inhalation of dust) value of 920mg/L (4 hours) (CERI Hazard Data 2001-31 (2002)).

Name: 2',4-Dichloro-alpha,alpha,alpha-trifluoro-4'-nitro-m-toluenesulfonanilide; Flusulfamide
Rationale for classification: Based on the dog LC50 (4 hour inhalation) value of 0.079mg/L (Agricultural Chemical Registration Data (1990)).

Name: 2-Pentanone
Rationale for classification: There is the description in the inhalation exposure test using a guinea pigs that it died from 50000ppm of 50-minute exposure (4-hour equivalent 36.478mg/L) (ACGIH 7th, 2001), or 50000ppm of 30 - 60-minute exposure (4-hour equivalent 21.974mg/L at the time of considering it as exposure for 30 minutes) (PATTY 4th, 1994). LC50 (4 hours) value is judged that it became 21.974mg/L or more, and it was set as category 5.

Name: m-Chloroaniline
Rationale for classification: Based on the rat LD50 (4 hour inhalation exposure) value of 0.783mg/L (equivalent to 150ppm) (MOE Risk Assessment vol.2 (2003)) was higher than the saturated vapour concentration of 90 ppm under a saturated vapour pressure of 9Pa (20degC), the substance was considered as "mist exposure."

Name: 1,3-Benzenediol
Rationale for classification: Based on rat LC50 value by 1 hour exposure: 21.3mg/L (4 hour equivalent: 5.33mg/L (IUCLID 2000)), it was set as Category 5.

Name: 2,4,6-Trichloro-1,3,5-triazine
Rationale for classification: Based on the LC50 value of 0.0911mg/L calculated from the testing data of rat LC50 (inhalation of dust) of 0.17mg/L (SIDS (2005)), 0.086mg/L (SIDS (2005)) and 0.201mg/L (SIDS(2005)).

Name: Glutaraldehyde
Rationale for classification: Category 2 because of ENDPOINT: LC50; VALUE (lower): 0.48 mg/L

Name: Adiponitrile
Rationale for classification: Based on the testing data of rat LC50 (inhalation of dust/mist) of 1.71mg/L (SIDS, 1998).

Name: 2-(4-Bromodifluoromethoxyphenyl)-2-methylpropyl 3-phenoxybenzyl ether; Hhalfenprox
Rationale for classification: Based on the rat LC50 (inhalation route) value of 0.36mg/L (Agricultural Chemical Registration Data (1993)).

Name: thiacloprid
Rationale for classification: It was set as category 4 based on that the female rat LC50 of the inhalation exposure examination is about 1.223mg/L (Agricultural Chemical Registration Data).

Name: Decan-1-ol
Rationale for classification: Saturated vapor pressure level of this substance (20degC)is 0.06 mg/L. Since LC50 value with 4 mg/L of the 2-hour inhalation exposure test employing mice (the 6th volume (2008) of the MOE Risk Assessment, IUCLID (2000)) is larger than saturated vapor pressure level, the mist standard is applied. Since 4-hour equivalent LC50 value is 2 mg/L, it was classified into Category 4.

Name: 2-isopropyloxyphenyl N-methylcarbamate
Rationale for classification: Calculated based on rat LC50 (1 hour) value : 1.44mg/L (4-hour equivalent 0.36mg/L) (RTECS, 2005, HSDB, 2005), LC50 (4 hours, aerosol) value : >0.5mg/L (IUCLID, 2000, HSDB, 2005), LC50 (4 hours, dust) value: 0.654mg/L (IUCLID, 2000) and >0.654mg/L (HSDB, 2005). Since the calculation was lower than lowest values, 0.36mg/L of lowest values was adopted and set it to category 2.

Name: Endosulfan
Rationale for classification: Based on that both male rats LC50 = 0.0346mg/L and female LC50 = 0.0126mg/L (Agricultural-Chemicals abstracts) were in the scope of category 1, it was classified into category 1.

Name: fensulfothion
Rationale for classification: The saturated vapor pressures concentrations pressure of this product is 0.0663ppm (0.00084mg/L), and it is thought that the inhalation study was done in mist. It was set as Category 1 based on LC50 = 0.0283mg/L calculated from eight data of rat LC50 value (ACGIH (2001), PATTY (5th, 2001), PD No.44 (1980), JMPR 239 (1972)).

Name: 2,4-Imidazolidinedione, 1,3-dichloro-5,5-dimethyl-
Rationale for classification: Since death was seen at rat 1 hour exposure tests: 20g/m3 (4 hour equivalent: 5mg/L (upper limit of Category 4)) (RTECS (2004)), it was set as Category 5.

Name: 2,3,5,6-Tetrachloro-p-benzoquinone
Rationale for classification: This substance is a solid whose saturated vapor pressure level is 0.000067 mg/L (25degC). It is written that LC50 value of the 4-hour inhalation exposure test employing rats is 2,485 mg/L (RTECS (2008)). The dust standard was applied and it was classified into Category 4.

Name: N-(4-tert-Butylbenzyl)-4-chloro-3-ethyl-1-methylpyrazole-5-carboxamide; Tebufenpyrad
Rationale for classification: Based on the rat LC50 (inhalation route) value of 2.7mg/L (Agricultural Chemical Registration Data (1993)).

Name: 1-({2-[2-chloro-4-(4-chlorophenoxy)phenyl]-4-methyl-1,3-dioxolan-2-yl}methyl)-1H-1,2,4-triazole
Rationale for classification: Based on the rat LC50 (inhalation route) value of 3.29mg/L (Agricultural Chemical Registration Data (1992)).

Name: 5-Amino-1-[2,6-dichloro-4-(trifluoromethyl)phenyl]-3-cyano-4-[(trifluoromethyl)sulfinyl]pyrazole; Fipronil
Rationale for classification: Based on the rat LC50 (inhalation route) value of 0.68mg/L (Agricultural Chemical Registration Data (1995)).

Name: tricarbonyl(eta-cyclopentadienyl)manganese
Rationale for classification: There was information (ACGIH (2001)) that 80% died from 4-hour exchange 0.06mg/L, and that LC50 was near 0.05 mg/L. So it was set as Category 1.

Name: N,N-Dimethylaniline
Rationale for classification: There was no 50% lethal dose data in mist inhalation. But there is information that 40% died within four days from inhalation exposure of mist 1.88mg/L for 4 hours (DFGOT vol.3 (1991)), and it is thought that LC50 goes into 1.0 - 5.0mg/L.. It was set as Category 4.

Name: p-Aminophenol
Rationale for classification: Based on the rat LC50 (inhalation of dust/mist) value of 1.48mg/L (IUCLID (2000)).

Name: Butyl acetate
Rationale for classification: It was set as Category 4 based on the rat inhalation test toxicity value of 391ppm (1.85mg/L) (ACGIH (2001)).

Name: Adipic acid
Rationale for classification: Since Saturated vapor pressure pressures concentrations is = 9.9ppm, it is thought that the inhalation study was done in mist. It was set as Category 5 based on rat LC50 = 7.7mg/L (CERI Hazard Data (1998)).

Name: Manganese N,N'-ethylenebis(dithiocarbamate)
Rationale for classification: Based on the rat LC50 (inhalation route) value of 7.38mg/L (Agricultural Chemical Registration Data (2005)).

Name: Acetamide, N,N-dimethyl-
Rationale for classification: Saturated vapor pressure level at 25degC is 2631.58 ppm (9.38 mg/L). Since LC50 value with 10.01 mg/L (SIDS (2001)) of the 1-hour inhalation exposure test employing rats is larger than saturated vapor pressure level, 4-hour equivalent LC50 value is 2.50 mg/L when applying the mist standard, and it was classified into Category 4. In addition, EU classification is Xn; R20/21 (EU-Annex I), and is equivalent to Category 3-4.

Name: N-[4-(p-Tolyloxy)benzyl]-1-methyl-3-ethyl-4-chloro-1H-pyrazole-5-carboxamide
Rationale for classification: The value of the lower one was adopted among LC50 values of a male and females. And it was set as category 4 based on LC50 = 1.50mg/L (Agricultural Chemical Registration Data).

Name: Cadmium oxide
Rationale for classification: Based on the leathal dose of 0.011 mg/L calculated from the testing data of human leathal dose (4 hour exposure to cadmium oxide fume) of 0.01mg/L (ACGIH 7th, 2001), 0.012 mg/L (EHC 134, 1992) and 0.011 mg/L (EHC 134, 1992).

Name: Sodium Pentachlorophenate
Rationale for classification: It was set as category 2 based on rat LC50 value 0.147mg/L/4H of an inhalation administration test (0.294mg/L/2H) (EHC 71, 1987).

Name: Lithium hydroxide monohydrate
Rationale for classification: Category 3 because of SPECIES: Rat; ENDPOINT: LC50; VALUE: 0.96mg/L/4H

Name: Zinc oxide
Rationale for classification: Since it was data of 5.7 or more mg/L in the rat (EU-RAR 43 (2004)), it was set as category 5.

Name: Divanadium pentaoxide
Rationale for classification: Based on the testing data of rat LC50 (4 hour inhalation exposure) of 4.29mg/L (IUCLID, 2000).

Name: phosphamidon
Rationale for classification: The vapor pressure of this product is 0.0033Pa (20degC). Saturated vapor pressure pressures concentrations was calculated with 0.03ppm, and 0.102mg/L was 8.3ppm, it imagined it as mist. Based on rat LC50 value: 0.102mg/L/4h, 0.135mg/L/4h, 0.16mg/L/4h (all are PIM(Poisons Information Monographs) 454, WHO/IPCS, 2001), the category was carried out with calculation. LC50 = 0.105mg/L/4h.

Name: ethoprophos
Rationale for classification: Category 2 because of "SPECIES: Rat; ENDPOINT: LC50(4hr.); VALUE:0.250 mg/L"(JMPR 961, 1999)

Name: 1,2,3,6-tetrahydro-N-(trichloromethylthio)phthalimide
Rationale for classification: Based on male rats LC50 (4 hours) level: 0.72mg/L (Agricultural-Chemicals abstracts), it was set as Category 3.

Name: tert-Butyl 4-({[(1,3-dimethyl-5-phenoxy-4-pyrazolyl)methylidene]aminooxy}methyl)benzoate; Fenpyroximate
Rationale for classification: Based on the rat LC50 (inhalation route) value of 0.33mg/L (Agricultural Chemical Registration Data (2002)).

Name: 2-Naphthol
Rationale for classification: It was set as Category 4 based on LC50 value of an inhalation administration test using female male rats, that is 2.2mg/L/4H (2200mg/m3/4H) (SIDS, 2006; IUCLID, 2000).

Name: 1,1'-[Iminodi(octamethylene)]diguanidine; Iminoctadine
Rationale for classification: Based on the rat LC50 (inhalation of dust/mist) value of 0.073mg/L (4 hours) (RTECS (2006)).

Name: Disodium chromate decahydrate
Rationale for classification: Rat LC50 = 0.104mg/L/4h to the sodium chromate anhydrides (CAS:7775-11-3) carried out in the state of mist (EU-RAR (2005)). Since a molecular weights of 10 hydrate (about 342) was as about twice as the anhydride (about 162). So it was converted to LC50 = about 0.2mg/L/4h, and it was set as Category 2.

Name: O,O-Diethyl O-2-quinoxalinyl phosphorothioate; Quinalphos
Rationale for classification: Based on the rat LC50 (inhalation route) value of 0.45mg/L (Agricultural Chemical Registration Data (1983)).

Name: Zinc bis(N,N'-dimethyldithiocarbamate)
Rationale for classification: Because the rat LC50 (inhalation of vapour) values of 0.07mg/L (4 hours) (IUCLID (2000)) and 0.081mg/L (4 hours) (IUCLID (2000)) exceeded 90% of the saturated vapour concentration of 9.9*10^(-6)ppm under a saturated vapour pressure of 7.5*10^(-9)mmHg (extrapolation) [equivalent to 1.0*10^(-6)Pa (extrapolation)] (SRC (2006)), the substance was considered as "mist exposure" and was classified as Category 2.

Name: (E)-3-(dimethylamino)-1-methyl-3-oxoprop-1-enyl dimethyl phosphate
Rationale for classification: Calculation was done based on rat LC50 (4 hours) value: 0.09mg/L (ACGIH, 2002) and LC50 (1 hour) value: 0.61-0.91mg/L (4-hour equivalent 0.15-0.23mg/L) (ACGIH, 2002). Since the calculated values were 0.09mg/L, they were set to category 2.

Name: Nonan-1-ol
Rationale for classification: Saturated vapor pressure level at 25degCis 0.18 mg/L.. Since LC50 value of 2-hour inhalation exposure test employing mice is 5,500 mg/m3 (the 6th volume (2008) of the MOE Risk Assessment, Patty (5th, 2001)), the mist standard is applied. 4-hour equivalent LC50 value is 2.75 mg/L, and it was classified into Category 4 by applying the mist standard.

Name: N-methyldithiocarbamic acid
Rationale for classification: Based on the rat LC50 (inhalation route) value of 1.98mg/L (4 hours) (Agricultural Chemical Registration Data (1984)).

Name: ferbam
Rationale for classification: Category 2 because of "SPECIES: Rat; ENDPOINT: LC50(4hr.); VALUE: 0.4mg/L"(HSDB, 2006)

Name: endothal
Rationale for classification: Since it was rat inhalation LC50 (mist, 4 hours) = 1.85mg/L (Agricultural Chemical Registration Data (1994)), it was set as Category 4.

Name: m-Phenylene-bis(methylamine)
Rationale for classification: Based on rat LC50 (1 hour) value: 3.75mg/L (4-hour equivalent 0.938mg/L) (ACGIH 7th, 2001) and LC50 (4 hours) value: 0.8mg/L (SIDS, 2001), it was set as Category 3.

Name: cartap hydrochloride
Rationale for classification: It was set as Category 4 based on rat LC50 = 3.5mg/L/4H (Agricultural Chemical Registration Data (non-submitted)).

Name: Emamectin benzoate
Rationale for classification: It was set as category 4 based on rat LC50 = 1.93mg/L (Agricultural Chemical Registration Data) of an inhalation exposure test.

Name: Cyanamide, calcium salt (1:1)
Rationale for classification: About inhalation, there is description of "LC50 are maximum allowable concentrations, and 13g or more of 50% aqueous solutions of calcium cyanamide per m3" (Agricultural Chemical Registration Data (2000)). And LC50 became >6.5mg/L (mist), it was set as Category 5.

Name: Carbofuran
Rationale for classification: It was set as Category 1 based on 75% wettable powder guinea-pig LC50 (4 hours) value: 0.045mg/L (equivalent 0.03375mg/L) (ACGIH, 2004).

Name: Methomyl
Rationale for classification: Based on 25% wettable powder rat (male) LC50 (1 hour) value: 1.99mg/L (4-hour equivalent 0.498mg/L), and 35.56% liquid medicine rat (female) LC50 (1 hour) value: 0.61mg/L (4-hour equivalent 0.15mg/L) (all are agricultural-chemicals abstracts), the lower value was adopted and it was set as Category 2.

Name: O-Ethyl S,S-diphenyl phosphorodithioate; Edifenphos; EDDP
Rationale for classification: Based on the rat LC50 (4 hour inhalation of vapour) value of 0.65mg/L (HSDB (2006)) exceeded 90% of the saturated vapour concentration (3.6*10^(-4)ppm) under a saturated vapour pressure of 2.70*10^(-7)mmHg (25degC) [equivalent to 36.0microPa (25degC)] (HSDB (2006)), the substance was considered as "mist exposure" and was classified as Category 3.

Name: N-[2-[1-(4-Chlorophenyl)-1H-pyrazole-3-yloxymethyl]phenyl]-N-methoxycarbamic acid methyl ester
Rationale for classification: It was set as Category 3 based on rat LC50 = 0.58mg/L. (Agricultural Chemical Registration Data) that was a result of the inhalation study done by melting to a solvent in order to make it a diameter which can be inhaled.

Name: O,O-Diethyl O-5-phenyl-3-isoxazolyl phosphorothioate; Isoxathion
Rationale for classification: Based on the rat LC50 (inhalation route) value of 2.0mg/L (Agricultural Chemical Registration Data (1985)).

Name: Tetrachloroisophthalonitrile
Rationale for classification: Based on the rat LC50 (inhalation route) value of 0.1mg/L (4 hours) (EHC183 (1996)).

Name: 1,1-Dimethyl-4,4-bipyridinium dichloride
Rationale for classification: It was set as Category 1 rat  LC50 = 0.00084mg/L (Agricultural Chemical Registration Data (1991)).

Name: Atrazine
Rationale for classification: In both LC50 >5.82mg/L (Agricultural Chemical Registration Data, 2002) and >5.148mg/L (Agricultural Chemical Registration Data, 1991) of an inhalation exposure test using rats, no death cases were repoted.  But the oral acute toxicities of category 4 were indicated, it was set as Category 5. In addition, the saturated concentration of this product is 3.81*10^(-4)ppm (equivalent 3.36*10^(-6)mg/L), and it is presumed that all inhalation tests are done in dust mists conditions.

Name: Stannane, tributylfluoro-
Rationale for classification: It was set as Category 2 based on rat inhalation LC50 value of 0.4ppm/4H (= 0.00504mg/L) (ACGIH 7th, 2001).

Name: paraquat-dimethylsulfate
Rationale for classification: It was set as Category 1 since all three data (ACGIH (2001), EHC 39 (1984)) were 0.05mg/L or less except the time when dust sizes is large.

Name: O-Ethyl O-4-nitrophenyl phenylphosphonothioate; EPN
Rationale for classification: Based on the rat LC50 (4 hours) value of 0.0265mg/L, calculated from the testing data of rat LC50 (inhalation) of 0.106mg/L (1 hour) (MOE Risk Assessment vol. 4 (2005)).

Name: caesium hydroxide
Rationale for classification: The value of 0.02mg/L was found in the inhalation LC50 data in which the animal and time of exposure was unknown (RTECS (2004)), it was considered as dust inhalation "category 1". Data that human LC50 (?): 0.005mg/L was also in the same former literature.

Name: 2-[(Thiocyanatomethyl)sulfanyl]-1,3-benzothiazole
Rationale for classification: Saturated vapor pressure level at 25degCis 0.00041 ppm (4*10^-6 mg/L). Since LC50 value with 0.1 mg/L of 4-hour inhalation exposure test employing rats (CERI/NITE Hazard Assessment Report (2008)) was larger than saturated vapor pressure level, it was classified into Category 2 by applying the dust and mist standard.

Name: O-4-Bromo-2,5-dichlorophenyl O-methyl phenylphosphorothioate
Rationale for classification: It was set as Category 3 based on 0.9mg/kg/4H which is the lower value among the rat LC50 = 0.9 and 1.65mg/kg/4H of JMPR (WHO Pesticide Residues Series 5, 1975) in Priority 1 document.

Name: S-Ethyl hexahydro-1H-azepine-1-carbothioate; Molinate
Rationale for classification: Based on the rat LC50 (inhalation route) value of 1.39mg/L (Agricultural Chemical Registration Data (1989)).

Name: Fenamiphos
Rationale for classification: Category 2 because of "SPECIES: Rat;  ENDPOINT: LC50 ; VALUE: 0.091-0.10 mg/L (4 h)" (JMPR 929, 1997)

Name: cadmium distearate, pure
Rationale for classification: It was set as Category 2 based on rat LC50 = 0.13mg/L/2H (0.065mg/L/4H by 4-hour exchange) (RTECS, 2004).

Name: 2,2'-[oxybis(methylene)]bisoxirane
Rationale for classification: Based on rate LC50 (4 hours) value: 200ppm (equivalent 1.06mg/L) (ACGIH 7th, 2001, PATTY 4th, 1994), it was set as Category 4.

Name: O,O-Dimethyl S-2-[1-(N-methylcarbamoyl)ethylthio]ethyl phosphorothioate; Vamidothion
Rationale for classification: Based on the rat LC50 (inhalation of dust/mist) value of 1.730mg/L (4 hours) (RTECS (2006)).

Name: pirimicarb
Rationale for classification: Based on the value (0.5mg/L) converted from oral LC50 (6h) = 0.3mg/L (JMPR375 (1976), HSDB (2003)) in a rat into exposure for 4 hours, it was set as category 2. In addition, the saturated concentration of this product is about 4*10^(-5)mg/L (4*10^(-3)ppm), it is presumed that the experiment was conducted in the state of the particulate.

Name: N',N'-dimethylcarbamoyl(methylthio)methylenamine N-methylcarbamate
Rationale for classification: It was set as category 2 based on the statement (Agricultural Chemical Registration Data) of LC50 = 0.064mg/L of the rats acute inhalation toxicity study.

Name: 6-methyl-1,3-dithiolo[4,5-b]quinoxalin-2-one
Rationale for classification: Based on the rat LC50 (inhalation route) value of 2.16mg/L (4 hours) (Agricultural Chemical Registration Data).

Name: Triglycidyl isocyanurate
Rationale for classification: It was set as Category 3 based on rat inhalation (dust) LC50 = 650mg/m3 (CICAD 8 (1998)).

Name: chlorophenol
Classification: Acute toxicity (inhalation: dust, mist) - o-:Classification not possible, m-:Classification not possible, p-:Category 4
Rationale for classification:
Based on mouse LC50=49 mg/L (DFGOT vol.1 (1991)) of the inhalation test carried out in mist, it carried out the outside of Category.
O-body: datum without.
M-body: datum without.
P-body: saturated vapor pressure pressures concentrations is 128.7ppm (0.677mg/L), and it was set to category 4 based on rat LC50 = 1.01mg/L (IUCLID (2000)) obtained by the test considered that the dust performed.

Name: O-Ethyl O-2-(isopropoxycarbonyl)phenyl N-isopropylphosphoramidothioate; Isofenphos
Rationale for classification: Based on the LC50 value of 0.144mg/L calculated from the testing data of rat LC50 (inhalation of dust/mist) of 0.144mg/L (4 hours) (RTECS (2006)), 0.2mg/L (4 hours) (IUCLID (2000)) and 0.3mg/L (4 hours) (HSDB (2006)).

Name: 5-ethoxy-3-trichloromethyl-1,2,4-thiadiazole
Rationale for classification: Based on the rat LC50 (inhalation route) value of 0.8mg/L (Agricultural Chemical Registration Data (1991)).

Name: Ethyl 2-[(dimethoxyphosphinothioyl)thio]-2-phenylacetate; Phenthoate; PAP
Rationale for classification: Based on the rat LC50 (inhalation route) value of 3.17mg/L (Agricultural Chemical Registration Data (1980)).

Name: S-benzyl O,O-diisopropyl phosphorothioate
Rationale for classification: Based on the rat LC50 (inhalation route) value of 0.34mg/kg (Agricultural Chemical Registration Data (1987)).

Name: [(2-chlorophenyl)methylene]malononitrile
Rationale for classification: Since particulate aerosol inhalation LC50 of rat was 0.5 or less in 4-hour translation, it was set as Category 2.

Name: dinoseb acetate
Rationale for classification: Since rat inhalation LC50 (4h) = 1.3mg/L (RTECS (1997)), it was set as category 4. In addition, the saturated concentration of this product is about 0.01mg/L, and it is presumed that the inhalation study is done in dust and mists conditions.

Name: Parathion, methyl-
Rationale for classification: The sexual differences which exceeds the difference during an examination on 11 rat LC50 value (EHC 145 (1993), ATSDR (2001), JMPR 902 (1995)) is not acknowledged. It was set as Category 2 based on 0.0611mg/L calculated by statistical work including males and females.

Name: O,O-diethyl ethylthiomethyl phosphorodithioate
Rationale for classification: The saturated vapor pressures concentrations pressure of this product is 1.0ppm (0.011mg/L). The lower value of the data of both sexes in rat 1 examination (ACGIH (2005)), this is indicated to have done in mist, was adopted. And it was set as Category 1 based on LC50 = 0.0028mg/L..

Name: disulfoton
Rationale for classification: It was set as Category 1 based on female rat LC50 = about 0.015mg/L (Agricultural Chemical Registration Data (1987)).

Name: naled
Rationale for classification: Category 2 because of SPECIES: Rat; ENDPOINT: LC50(4hr.); VALUE: 0.19mg/L

Name: Paraformaldehyde
Rationale for classification: Category 4 because of "SPECIES: Rat (aspiration); ENDPOINT: LC50; VALUE:1.07mg/L" (RTECS, 2005)

Name: aldrin
Rationale for classification: From description that nine among ten rats died from 1-hour exposure of 0.108mg/L (4-hour equivalent 0.027mg/L) in the vapors and particles inhalation exposure tests (ATSDR (2002)), it was set as Category 1.

Name: isopropyl 3-[[(ethylamino)methoxyphosphinothioyl]oxy]crotonate
Rationale for classification: If the lower one is taken among rat LC50 values of both sex in 4-hour inhalation toxicity study , they are LC50 = 3.02mg/L and LC50 = 3.3mg/L, respectively (drugs application materials). And it was set as Category 4 based on the lowest value LC50=3.02 mg/L..

Name: N,N-Dimethyl-1,2,3-trithian-5-amine
Rationale for classification: It was set as Category 4 based on rat LC50 = 1.02mg/L which is the lower value of LC50 = 1.02mg/L (male) and LC50 = 1.20mg/L (female) (Agricultural Chemical Registration Data).

Name: Diazinon
Rationale for classification: It was set as Category 4 based on Rat LC50 (4 hours) value: 3.1mg/L (Agricultural-Chemicals abstracts).

Name: 2,3-dicyano-1,4-dithiaanthraquinone
Rationale for classification: Based on the rat LC50 (inhalation route) value of 1.82mg/L (Agricultural Chemical Registration Data (1975)).

Name: sulfotep
Rationale for classification: Since the saturated vapor pressures concentrations pressure of this product is 0.2ppm, it is thought that the inhalation experiments was conducted in mist conditions. Based on LC50 = 0.038mg/L which is lower value among two rat data (ACGIH (2005), DFGOT vol.13 (1999), PATTY (5th, 2001)), it was set as Category 1.

Name: chlorophacinone
Rationale for classification: Among the values of an rat inhalation administration test which are >0.75mg/L/4H ( >3mg/L/1H) (HSDB, 2003; RTECS, 1997) and 0.007mg/L/4H (7.0microg/L/4H) (HSDB, 2003), the lower value of 0.007mg/L/4H were adopted. And it was set as Category 1.

Name: dinocap
Rationale for classification: It was set as category 2 based on rat LC50 (4h) = 0.36mg/L (RTECS (2003)). In addition, it is presumed that the saturated concentration of this product is very low, and the inhalation test is done in mist conditions.

Name: alpha-cyano-3-phenoxybenzyl 2,2-dimethyl-3-(2-methylprop-1-enyl)cyclopropanecarboxylate
Rationale for classification: Since mouse LC50 (3h) = 570mg/m3 (0.43mg/L as a 4h conversion value) (poisonous and deleterious substances handling guide (Jiji Press Co., 2001)), it was set as category 2.

Name: Cyclohexane, 5-isocyanato-1-(isocyanatomethyl)-1,3,3-trimethyl-
Rationale for classification: Since the saturated vapor pressures concentrations pressure of this product is 0.396ppm, it is presumed that LC50 value acquired by all inhalation study was acquired in mist conditions. Based on LC50 = 0.786mg/L calculated by the technical guide using three test results of rats (CERI Hazard Data (2000), MOE Risk Assessment(2004), and ACGIH (2001)), it was set as Category 3.

Name: O-4-bromo-2-chlorophenyl O-ethyl S-propyl phosphorothioate
Rationale for classification: Based on the rat LC50 (inhalation route) value of 4.45mg/kg (Agricultural Chemical Registration Data (1984)).

Name: 1,1'-Dimethyl-4,4'-bipyridinium salts (except paraquat dichloride)
Rationale for classification:
Based on the LD 50 value of 0.005mg/L calculated from the testing data of rat LC50 (6-hour inhalation of dust) of 0.001mg/L, 0.01mg/L, 0.01mg/L and 0.006mg/L (EHC 39 (1984)).
Note: Classified using data on Cl salts

Name: 2-Chloro-1-(2,4-dichlorophenyl)vinyl diethyl phosphate; Chlorfenvinphos; CVP
Rationale for classification: Based on the rat LC50 (inhalation of dust/mist) value of 0.05mg/L (4 hours) (HSDB (2006)).

Name: Diisopropyl 1,3-dithiolan-2-ylidenemalonate; isoprothiolane
Rationale for classification: It was set as category 4 based on rat inhalation (particulate and mist) LC50 value ( >2.77mg/L: Agricultural Chemical Registration Data, 2001). In addition, although LC50 value was not specified, 4 is in the range of 1.0 <Category 4 = <5.0mg/L.

Name: 2-Amino-4-[hydroxy(methyl)phosphinoyl]butyric acid; Glufosinate
Rationale for classification: Based on the rat LC50 (inhalation route) value of 1.26mg/L (Agricultural Chemical Registration Data (1986)).

Name: alpha-Cyano-3-phenoxybenzyl 2-(4-chlorophenyl)-3-methylbutyrate; Fenvalerate
Rationale for classification: Based on the rat LC50 (4 hour inhalation) value of 2.810mg/L (Agricultural Chemical Registration Data (1995)).

Name: 2-Thioxo-3,5-dimethyltetrahydro-2H-1,3,5-thiadiazine; Dazomet
Rationale for classification: Based on the rat LC50 (inhalation route) value of 7.29mg/L (Agricultural Chemical Registration Data (1990)).

Name: 4,6-Dinitro-o-cresol
Rationale for classification: Based on the rat LC50 (4-hour inhalation of dust/mist) value of 0.23mg/L (EHC 220 (2000).

Name: Fenthion
Rationale for classification: It was classified into category 3 based on the lower value among rat LC50 = 1.2 and 0.8mg/L (Agricultural-Chemicalsd abstracts).

Name: 2,3-Dihydro-2,2-dimethyl-7-benzo[b]furyl N-(dibutylamino)thio-N-methylcarbamate; Carbosulfan
Rationale for classification: Based on the rat LC50 (inhalation exposure) value of 0.15mg/L (4 hours) (Agricultural Chemical Registration Data (1981)).

Name: Methyl isothiocyanate
Rationale for classification: Based on the rat LC50 (inhalation of dust) value of 0.48mg/L (4 hours) (HSDB (2006)).

Name: Distannoxane, hexabutyl-
Rationale for classification: Based on rat inhalation LC50 value 65mg/m3/4H (= 0.065mg/L/4H) (DFGOT 1 (1991); CICAD 14 (1999); ATSDR (2005)), it was set as Category 2.

Name: Parathion
Rationale for classification: It is based on rat LC50 0.032mg/L (4hours) (a statistically calculated values, ACGIH (2003) others).

Name: ethion
Rationale for classification: There are rat LC50 (4 hours) value: 0.864mg/L (ACGIH, 2003) and 0.45mg/L (ACGIH, 2003, ATSDR, 2001). Adopting the lower value, it was set as Category 2

Name: Lindane
Rationale for classification: Category 4 because of "SPECIES: Rat; ENDPOINT: LC50(4hr.; VALUE: 1.6mg/L"(DFGOT vol.16, 2001; EHC 124, 1991)

Name: 4-(2,4-dichlorobenzoyl)-1,3-dimethyl-5-pyrazolyl 4-toluenesulfonate
Rationale for classification: Based on the rat LC50 (inhalation route) value of 2.5mg/L (Agricultural Chemical Registration Data (1992)).

Name: 4-Methyl-1,3-phenylene diisocyanate
Rationale for classification: Based on the LC50 value (4 hours) of 897ppm, calculated from the testing data of rat LC50 (6 hour inhalation of dust/mist) of 4.27mg/L (PATTY 4th, 2000), exceeded the saturated vapor concentration (660 ppm) under a saturated vapour pressure of 67 Pa (25degC) (CERI Hazard Data 97-20, 1998), the substance is likely to contain mist, despite its description as vapour.

Name: dieldrin
Rationale for classification: Category 1 because of "SPECIES: Rat; ENDPOINT: LC50; VALUE: 0.013mg/L"(RTECS, 2005)

Name: BHC or HCH
Rationale for classification: It was set as category 3 base on rat inhalation LC50 (4hr) = 0.69mg/L (RTECS (2004)). In addition, considering the saturated concentration (about 0.01mg/L) computed from this substance's steam pressure (0.1Pa at 25degC), it was presumed that the experiment was conducted in dust and mists conditions.

Name: 1-Chloro-2-(chloromethyl)benzene
Rationale for classification: Since LC50 value of 4-hour aerosol inhalation exposure test employing rats (OECD TG 403, GLP)is 2.8 mg/L (SIDS (2004)), it was classified into Category 4.

Name: Chlordimeform
Rationale for classification: It was set as Category 4 based on rat inhalation LC50 (1hr) = 14.7mg/L (4-hour equivalent 4.35mg/L) (JMPR206 (1972)). In addition, the saturated concentration of this product is about 0.47ppm (3.7mg/m3) (20degC), and it is presumed that the inhalation study was done in mist conditions.

Name: Aniline
Rationale for classification: Based on the LC50 value (4 hours) of 2.3mg/L, calculated from the testing data of rat LC50 (inhalation of vapor) of 5.1mg/L (4 hours) (CaPSAR (1994)), 3.3mg/L (4 hours) (EU-RAR No.50 (2004)), 3.19mg/L(4 hours) (EU-RAR No.50 (2004)), 1.82mg/L (4 hours) (EU-RAR No.50 (2004)) was higher than of the saturated vapor concentration (400ppm) under a saturated vapour pressure of 0.04kPa (25degC) (ICSC (2004)), the substance was considered as "mist".

Name: Dimethyl 2,2-dichlorovinyl phosphate; Dichlorvos
Rationale for classification: Because the LC50 values of 50.3ppm, 38ppm, 72ppm, 57.9ppm and 49.4ppm, calculated respectively from the testing data of rat LC50 (1 hour) of 0.455mg/L (EHC 79 (1988)), LC50 (4 hours) of 0.34mg/L (EHC 79 (1988)), 0.65mg/L, 0.523mg/L and 0.447mg/L (PATTY (4th, 1999)), exceeded the saturated vapour concentration (20.9ppm) under a saturated vapour pressure of 0.0158mmHg (25degC; equivalent to 2.11Pa), the substance was considered as "mist exposure" and was classified based on the LC50 of 0.266mg/kg (4-hour inhalation of dust/mist).

Name: N,N'-ethylenebis(thiocarbamoylthiozinc) bis(N,N-dimethyldithiocarbamate)
Rationale for classification: Based on the rat LC50 (inhalation route) value of 0.104mg/L (4 hours) (Agricultural Chemical Registration Data (1986)).

Name: Distillates (petroleum), straight-run middle
Rationale for classification: Inhalation study of gasoline was done that aerosol is mixed with steam, it was thought that aerosol is main. And It was set as Category 4 based on value 4.6mg/L (IUCLID (2000)) that is lower value of rat inhalation LC50.

Name: Distillates (petroleum), solvent-refined heavy paraffinic; Distillates (petroleum), solvent-refined light naphthenic; Lubricating oils (petroleum), C15-30, hydrotreated neutral oil-based; Lubricating oils (petroleum), C20-50, hydrotreated neutral oil-based; Petroleum; Paraffin oils
Rationale for classification: Category 4 because of "SPECIES: Rat;  ENDPOINT: LC50 = 2.18 mg/L." (IUCLID, 2000)

Name: Distillates (petroleum), solvent-refined heavy paraffinic; Distillates (petroleum), solvent-refined light naphthenic; Lubricating oils (petroleum), C15-30, hydrotreated neutral oil-based; Lubricating oils (petroleum), C20-50, hydrotreated neutral oil-based; Petroleum; Paraffin oils
Rationale for classification: Category 4 because of "SPECIES: Rat;  ENDPOINT: LC50 = 2.18 mg/L." (IUCLID, 2000)

Name: 2,3-dihydro-2,2-dimethyl-7-benzofuryl 2,4-dimethyl-6-oxa-5-oxo-3-thia-2,4-diazadecanoate
Rationale for classification: It was set as Category 2 based on LC50 = 0.24mg/L.: this is the lower value of LC50 = 0.24mg/L. and LC50 = 0.16mg/L (Agricultural Chemical Registration Data) by the inhalation exposure test using rats.

Name: Esfenvalerate
Rationale for classification: It was set as Category 2 based on inhalation by mists in a rat LC50 (4hr) = 0.48mg/L (JMPR (2002)).

Name: monocrotophos
Rationale for classification: Calculated based on rat LC50 (4 hours) value: 0.063mg/L and 0.1mg/L (ACGIH, 2002), and LC50 (1 hour) value:0.163mg/L (4-hour equivalent 0.0408mg/L) (ACGIH, 2002). The calculation value was lower than these lowest value. And 0.0408 mg/L of lowest value was adopted and set it to category 1.

Name: 2-tert-Butylimino-3-isopropyl-5-phenyltetrahydro-4H-1,3,5-thiadiazin-4-one; buprofezin
Rationale for classification: It was set as Category 4 based on LC50 value >4.57mg/L/4H using a rat of the inhalation exposure test (dust mists) (Agricultural Chemical Registration Data (2001)).

Name: Fluvalinate
Rationale for classification: Based on the inhalation to a rat LC50 (4hr) = 0.439ppm (since the saturated concentration is 0.002mg/L, it is presumed that the inhalation study is performed in mist conditions) (RTECS (2003)), it was set as Category 2.

Name: Distillates (petroleum), solvent-refined heavy paraffinic; Distillates (petroleum), solvent-refined light naphthenic; Lubricating oils (petroleum), C15-30, hydrotreated neutral oil-based; Lubricating oils (petroleum), C20-50, hydrotreated neutral oil-based; Petroleum; Paraffin oils
Rationale for classification: Category 4 because of "SPECIES: Rat;  ENDPOINT: LC50 = 2.18 mg/L." (IUCLID, 2000)

Name: Distillates (petroleum), solvent-refined heavy paraffinic; Distillates (petroleum), solvent-refined light naphthenic; Lubricating oils (petroleum), C15-30, hydrotreated neutral oil-based; Lubricating oils (petroleum), C20-50, hydrotreated neutral oil-based; Petroleum; Paraffin oils
Rationale for classification: Category 4 because of "SPECIES: Rat;  ENDPOINT: LC50 = 2.18 mg/L." (IUCLID, 2000)

Name: propaphos
Rationale for classification: It was set as Category 1 based on LC50 = 0.039mg/L on the both sex rat (Agricultural Chemical Registration Data).

Name: O,O-dimethyl phthalimidomethyl S-phosphorodithioate
Rationale for classification: Based on the lower one among rat inhalation LC50 (4 hours) = 0.054mg/L (RTECS (2003)) and LC50 (1 hour) = 2.76mg/L [4-hour conversion value 0.69mg/L] (HSDB (2003)), it was set as Category 2.

Name: Cadmium
Rationale for classification: Category 1 because of "SPECIES: Rat; ENDPOINT: LC50; VALUE: 0.0031 mg/L "(RTECS (2005)

Name: iodoform
Rationale for classification: Based on rat LC50 (7 hours) value: 165ppm (4-hour equivalent 4.64mg/L) (ACGIH 7th, 2001) and 183ppm (4-hour equivalent 5.15mg/L) (PATTY 4th, 1994), the lower value was adopted. And it was set as Category 4.

Name: 2,2-Dichloropropionic acid
Rationale for classification: Since rat LC50 value of the inhalation exposure test (dust mists) is indicated male and females: >4.15mg/L/4H (100% purity equivalent: >1.25mg/L/4H))(Agricultural Chemical Registration Data (1999)), it was set as Category 4.

Name: lithium hydride
Rationale for classification: There is a report about the rat inhalation toxicity studies in which 2/10 died at 0.022mg/L/4H and 4/10 died (DFGOTvol.3 (1991)) at 0.036mg/L/7H (equivalent: 0.063mg/L/4H). And it is strongly expected that LC50 is 0.05 - 0.5mg/L/4H, it was set as category 2.

Name: Fentin hydroxide
Rationale for classification: It was set as Category 2 based on rat inhalation LC50 = 0.06mg/L/4H (JMPR 827, 1991).

Name: Sodium nitrite
Rationale for classification: Category 1 because of "SPECIES: Rat; ENDPOINT: LC50; VALUE: 0.0055mg/L/4H; VALUE: 5.5mg/m3/4H" (RTECS, 2004)

Name: Zinc chloride
Rationale for classification: LC50 value decided for the animal is not acquired. But the humans deaths after exposure is reported though an exposure level was unknown (ACGIH (2001), PATTY (5th, 2001)). Therefore, it was set to category 1-5.

Name: Hydrochloric acid
Rationale for classification: Rat LC50 = 1.68mg/L / 1h is the aerosol data (SIDS (2002)). It was set as category 2 based on 4-hour value 0.42mg/L of this value.

Name: Ethyl 2-[4-(6-chloro-2-quinoxalinyloxy)phenoxy]propionate; Quizalofop-ethyl
Rationale for classification: Based on the rat LC50 (inhalation route) value of 5.8mg/L (Agricultural Chemical Registration Data (1983)).

Name: Sulfuric acid
Rationale for classification: Based on rat LC50 value (4 hour exposure): 0.375mg/L (1-hour exposure) and : 347ppm (4 hour equivalent: 0.347mg/L) (all are (SIDS and 2001)), it was set as Category 2

Name: Aniline, N-(1-methylethyl)-
Rationale for classification: Category 4 because of "SPECIES: Rat (aspiration); ENDPOINT: LC50 = 1.2 mg/L /4H" (ACGIH, 2001)

Name: Nitric acid
Rationale for classification: Nitric acid did not exist as steam and gas, and it considered that all the data of LC50 was mist. Since all of five data were within the range of 0.05 - 0.5mg/L, it was set as Category 2.

Name: potassium nitrite
Rationale for classification: It was set as Category 5 based on mouse LC50 value 42mg/L/4H (85g/m3/2H) (RTECS, 1997).

Name: Sodium chlorite
Rationale for classification: Since there are two rat LC50 values: 0.23mg/L (the original is 230mg/m3) (RTECS (2003)) and purity equivalent 0.235mg/L (=0.29*0.809) (IUCLID (2000)), 0.23mg/L of higher toxicity was adopted and set to category 2.

Name: Copper monochloride
Rationale for classification: It was set as Category 3 based on mouse LC50 value 1.0mg/L (1008mg/m3) (RTECS, 2000) of an inhalation administration test.

Name: Potassium dichromate
Rationale for classification: Based on the rat LC50 (inhalation of dust/mist) of 0.099mg/L (EU-RAR No.53 (2005)).

Name: Mevinphos
Rationale for classification: Calculated on based on rat LC50 (1 hour) value: 14.4ppm (4-hour equivalent 0.0329mg/L) and 0.0098mg/L (4-hour equivalent 0.0025mg/L) (ACGIH, 2003), approximately 14ppm (4-hour equivalent 0.032mg/L) (PATTY 4th, 1994). Since the calculated values were 0.00609mg/L, they were set to category 1.

Name: Beryllium sulfate, Tetrahydrate
Rationale for classification: Based on the LC50 value of 0.029 mg BeSO4.4H2O/L calculated from the testing data of rat LC50 (4 hour inhalation) of 0.15 mg beryllium/m3 (DFGOT Vol.21 (2005)).

Name: Ammonium dichromate
Rationale for classification: It was set as Category 2 based on rat LC50 (4hr) = 0.2mg/L (EU-RAR (2005)) in inhalation study (mist).

Name: dioxathion
Rationale for classification: Since the saturated vapor pressures concentrations pressure of this product is 0.000115mg/L (6*10^(-7)ppm), it is thought that the inhalation study was done in mist. It was set as category 2 based on rat LC50 = 0.3495mg/L (ACGIH (2002)).

Name: S,S,S-tributylphosphorotrithioate
Rationale for classification: It was set as Category 3 based on mouse inhalation LC50 (1hr) = 3804mg/m3 (RTECS (2004)) (4-hour equivalent 0.951mg/L). The saturated concentration of this product is 0.0168ppm (equivalent 0.22mg/m3), and it is presumed that the experiment was conducted in mist conditions.

Name: 2-Cyclohexen-1-one, 3,5,5-trimethyl-
Rationale for classification: It done by higher concentrations than the saturated vapor pressure pressures concentrations, and based on LC50 = 7mg/L (SIDS (2003)) of the rat inhalation test considered to be mist tests. So it was set as Category 5

Name: Acrylic acid
Rationale for classification: Based on the LC50 value (4 hours) calculated from the testing data of rat LC50 (inhalation of mist) of 11.1 mg/L (1 hour) and 7.5 mg/L (2 hours) (EHC 191 (1997)). Of LC50 values of 2.8 and 3.8 mg/L (4 hours) calculated, the lower value was adopted for classification purposes.

Name: 2,3,5,6-Tetrafluoro-4-methylbenzyl (Z)-3-(2-chloro-3,3,3-trifluoro-1-propenyl)-2,2-dimethylcyclopropanecarboxylate; Tefluthrin
Rationale for classification: Based on the rat LC50 (inhalation route) value of 0.0371mg/L (Agricultural Chemical Registration Data (1992)).

Name: 3-chloro-N-(3-chloro-5-trifluoromethyl-2-pyridyl)-alpha,alpha,alpha-trifluoro-2,6-dinitro-p-toluidine
Rationale for classification: Based on the rat LC50 (inhalation route) value of 0.46mg/L (Agricultural Chemical Registration Data (1989)).

Name: 2-Hydroperoxy-2-phenylpropane
Rationale for classification: Saturated vapor pressure level of this substance at 25degC is 4 ppm. Since LC50 value of the 4-hour inhalation exposure test employing rats is 220 ppm (Patty (5th, 2001), IUCLID (2000)), equivalent is 1.4 mg/L by applying the mist standard, and it was classified into Category 4.

Name: Toxaphene
Rationale for classification: Particulate inhalation half fatal dose 3.4mg/L (1hr) of the rat (ATSDR (1986)) was converted into exposure for 4 hours to presume LC50: 0.85mg/L.. So it was set as Category 3.

Name: Distillates (petroleum), solvent-refined heavy paraffinic; Distillates (petroleum), solvent-refined light naphthenic; Lubricating oils (petroleum), C15-30, hydrotreated neutral oil-based; Lubricating oils (petroleum), C20-50, hydrotreated neutral oil-based; Petroleum; Paraffin oils
Rationale for classification: Category 4 because of "SPECIES: Rat;  ENDPOINT: LC50 = 2.18 mg/L." (IUCLID, 2000)

Name: Pyrethrins and Pyrethroids
Rationale for classification: Category 4 because of "SPECIES: Rat; ENDPOINT: LC50(4hr.); VALUE: 3.4mg/L"(ATSDR, 2003)

Name: 1-tert-Butyl-3-(2,6-diisopropyl-4-phenoxyphenyl)thiourea; Diafenthiuron
Rationale for classification: Based on the rat LC50 (inhalation route) value of 0.497mg/L (Agricultural Chemical Registration Data (1995)).

Name: Distillates (petroleum), solvent-refined heavy paraffinic; Distillates (petroleum), solvent-refined light naphthenic; Lubricating oils (petroleum), C15-30, hydrotreated neutral oil-based; Lubricating oils (petroleum), C20-50, hydrotreated neutral oil-based; Petroleum; Paraffin oils
Rationale for classification: Category 4 because of "SPECIES: Rat;  ENDPOINT: LC50 = 2.18 mg/L." (IUCLID, 2000)

Name: Oleum
Rationale for classification: It was set as Category 3 based on rat inhalation LC50 = 347ppm/1H (= 86.7ppm/4H = 0.63mg/L/4H, molecular weights are set to 178.14, and it is guessed as mist) (RTECS (1995)).

Name: Demeton-methyl
Classification: Acute toxicity (inhalation: dust, mist) - O-:Category 2; S-:Category 2
Rationale for classification:
The saturated vapor pressures concentrations pressure of this product is 0.396ppm (0.00373mg/L), and it is thought that the inhalation study was done in mist.
It was set as Category 2 based on LC50 = 0.427mg/L calculated from three data (JMPR 790 (1989)) of O-body: rat LC50 value.
It was set as Category 2 based on LC50=0.21mg/L calculated from four data (PATTY (5th, 2001)) of S-body: rat LC50 value.

Name: Rosin
Rationale for classification: Based on rat LC50 (6 hours) value: about 1.5mg/L (4 hour equivalent: about 2.3mg/L) (IUCLID, 2000).it was set as Category 4.

Name: Demeton (mixed isomers)
Classification: Acute toxicity (inhalation: dust, mist) - Mixture:Category 1; O-:Classification not possible; S-:Classification not possible
Rationale for classification:
Since the this vapor saturated vapor pressure of the mixture: material is 0.297ppm (0.003mg/L), it is thought that the inhalation study was done in mist. It was set as Category 1 based on LC50 = 0.0439mg/L calculated from four data (ACGIH (2002), PATTY (5th, 2001)) of rat LC50 value.
O-body: datum without.
S-body: datum without.

Name: diphacinone
Rationale for classification: The saturated vapor pressure concentrations calculated from this substance's steam pressure 1.37*10^(-5)mPa (25degC) is 1.35*10^(-7)mg/L, and each concentration (2mg/L, 6ug/L) used for the inhalation study is considered to be a dust. Therefore, it was classified into category 1 based on higher toxic value LC50 <6ug/L/4 hr (HSDB (2003)) among rat LC50 values.

Name: ethyl N-[2,3-dihydro-2,2-dimethylbenzofuran-7-yloxycarbonyl(methyl)aminothio]-N-isopropyl-beta-alaninate
Rationale for classification: It was set as Category 2 based on rat LC50 = 0.15mg/L (Agricultural Chemical Registration Data) in the inhalation exposure test (dust and mists).

Name: 2-Methyl-1,1'-biphenyl-3-ylmethyl (Z)-3-(2-chloro-3,3,3-trifluoro-1-propenyl)-2,2-dimethylcyclopropanecarboxylate; Bifenthrin
Rationale for classification: Based on the rat LC50 (inhalation route) value of 0.8mg/L (Agricultural Chemical Registration Data (2004)).

Name: 1,1':2',1''-Terphenyl
Rationale for classification: This substance is a solid whose saturated vapor pressure level at 25degCis 0.003 mg/L. As a result of having investigated the cited reference (Toxicol.Appl.Pharmacol.1 (1959)) about an inhalation exposure test employing rats described in ACGIH (7th, 2001), it said that there were 4/8 mortality in the high concentration, and no mortality in the low concentration in the 1-hour inhalation exposure test by 2 concentrations (3.56 mg/L, 0.88 mg/L) employing male and female rats. Therefore, when LC50 value was judged to be 3.56 mg/L and the dust standard was applied, it was classified into Category 3 from 4-hour equivalent LC50 value with 0.89 mg/L. In addition, this cited reference covers Terphenyl which contains this substance as one of isomeric forms.

Name: Stannane, tributyl-, mono(naphthenoyloxy) derivs
Rationale for classification: Because the rat LC50 (4 hour inhalation of vapour) value of 0.152mg/L (DFGOT Vol.1 (1990)) exceeded 90% of the saturated vapour concentration (9*10^(-4)ppm (equivalent to 1*10^(-5)mg/L)) under a saturated vapour pressure of 9*10^(-5)Pa (20degC) (EHC 116 (1990)), the substance was considered as "mist exposure" and was classified into Category 2.

Name: O,O-dimethyl-4-oxobenzotriazin-3-ylmethyl phosphorodithioate
Rationale for classification: Based on level LC50 = 0.126mg/L obtained by statistics calculation of six data of rat inhalation LC50 (4hr) level (PATTY (5th, 2001), JMPR 818 (1991), ACGIH (2002)), it was classified into category 2.

Name: 1-vinyl-2-pyrrolidone
Rationale for classification: Based on saturated vapor pressure level 12 Pa (EU-RAR (2003)) at 20degC, saturated vapor pressure at 20degC is 0.54 mg/L, and it was classified into Category 4 based on the report that LC50 value (4 hours) of rats was 3.07 mg/L (NICNAS (2000)). In addition, EU-Annex I, which is Xn; R20/21/22-48/20, is equivalent to the GHS Category 3 to 4.

Name: Benzene, 1-chloro-2-nitro-
Rationale for classification: It was set as Category 4 based on rat LC50 (4hr) = 495ppm (equivalent 3.18mg/L) (SIDS (2001)). In addition, the saturated concentration of this product is 24ppm, and it is presumed that the inhalation study was done in dust and mists conditions.

Name: pyraclofos
Rationale for classification: It was set as category 4 based on rat LC50 = 1.46mg/L (Agricultural Chemical Registration Data) of 4-hour exposure.

Name: fentin acetate
Rationale for classification: From rat inhalation LC50 value (male: 0.044mg/L/4H, female: 0.069mg/L/4H)(JMPR 827, 1991), the lower male data (male: 0.044mg/L/4H) was adopted, and it was set as Category 1.

Name: (4-chloro-2-methylphenoxy)acetic acid
Rationale for classification: Based on the rat LC50 (inhalation route) value of 0.3mg/L (4 hours) (Agricultural Chemical Registration Data (1987)).

Name: 2,4-Dichlorophenoxyacetic acid
Rationale for classification: There is no this product data. But was set as Category 4 based on that rat LC50 value of sodium salt and dimethylamine salt are ,respectively, >0.64mg/L and >3.7mg/L (no death case in 2.7mg/L, 2 death cases in 3.7mg/L)(all being 4-hour exposure)(Agricultural Chemical Registration Data, 1992).

Name: fonofos
Rationale for classification: Since the saturated vapor pressures concentrations pressure of this product is 0.49ppm, it is thought that the inhalation study was done in mist. Based on LC50 = 0.225mg/L (4-hour equivalent) which is the lower one among the rat inhalation 2 data (ACGIH (2001)), it was set as Category 2.

Name: o-Chloroaniline
Rationale for classification: Based on the LC50 value (4 hours) of 2.02mg/L (equivalent to 388ppm), calculated from the testing data of rat LC50 (1 hour) of 775ppm (CERI Hazard Data 99-25 (2000)), and the LC50 (4 hours) of 4.16mg/L (MOE Risk Assessment vol.3 (2004)) exceeded the saturated vapour concentration (350ppm) under a saturated vapour pressure of 35Pa (25degC), the substance was considered as "mist exposure" and was classified based on the LC50 (4 hours) value of 2.02mg/L representing the lower of the two data.

Name: o-Phenylenediamine
Rationale for classification: Based on the rat LC50 (inhalation of dust) value of 0.15mg/L (4 hours) (ACGIH (7th, 2001)).

Name: 2,4-Dimethylaniline
Rationale for classification: Saturated vapor pressure level of this substance (25degC)is 175 ppm (0.867 mg/L). Since LC50 value with 1.53 mg/L of the 4-hour inhalation exposure test employing rats (DFGOT vol.19 (1998)) was larger than saturated vapor pressure level, it was classified into Category 4 by applying the mist standard.

Name: 3,4-Dichloroaniline
Rationale for classification: Since it is written in EU-RAR (2006) that LC50 values of 4-hour aerosol inhalation exposure test employing rats are >0.631 mg/L (OECD TG403), and 3.3 mg/L, it was classified into Category 4 based on the definite value 3.3 mg/L.. In addition, in EU classification, T; 23/24/25 (EU-Annex I).

Name: S-(2,3-Dihydro-5-methoxy-2-oxo-1,3,4-thiadiazol-3-yl)methyl O,O-dimethyl phosphorodithioate; Methidathion; DMTP
Rationale for classification: Based on the rat LC50 (inhalation exposure) value of 0.109mg/L representing the lower of the two testing data, 0.109mg/L and 0.173mg/L (Agricultural Chemical Registration Data, 1993).

Name: cadusafos
Rationale for classification: It was set as Category 1 based on rat LC50 (4 hours) = 0.026mg/L of the inhalation toxicity study (Agricultural Chemical Registration Data).

Name: 2-tert-Butyl-5-(4-tert-butylbenzylthio)-4-chloro-3(2H)-pyridazinone; Pyridaben
Rationale for classification: Based on the rat LC50 (inhalation route) value of 0.62mg/L (Agricultural Chemical Registration Data (1987)).

Name: O-2,4-Dichlorophenyl O,O-diethyl phosphorothioate; Dichlofenthion; ECP
Rationale for classification: Based on the rat LC50 (inhalation route) value of 1.75mg/L (Agricultural Chemical Registration Data (1994)).

Name: Toluene, 4-tert-butyl-
Rationale for classification: Category 4 because of "SPECIES: Rat; ENDPOINT: LC50(1hr.); VALUE: 934ppm(4hr).; VALUE:1.41mg/L"(ACGIH 7th, 2001)

Name: Benzene, (dichloromethyl)-
Rationale for classification: It was set as Category 4 based on 4-hour converted values 4.3mg/L of rat LC50 = 654ppm (CERI Hazard Data (2000)).

Name: Nitrobenzene
Rationale for classification: Based on the testing data of rat LC50 (inhalation of dust/mist) of 2.92mg/L (MOE Risk Assessment vol. 2 (2003)) exceeded 90% of the saturated vapour concentration (1.62mg/L) under a saturated vapour pressure of 0.245mmHg (25degC) (MOE Risk Assessment vol. 2 (2003)), the substance was considered as "dust/mist."

Name: fosthiazate
Rationale for classification: It was set as category 3 based on 4-hour exposure LC50 = 0.558mg/L (Agricultural Chemical Registration Data) of rat inhalation (mist).

Name: Ethanaminium, 2-chloro-N,N,N-trimethyl-
Rationale for classification: It was set as Category 5 based on rat LC0 = 3.05mg/L and LC10-20 = 5.2mg/L (Agricultural Chemical Registration Data).

Name: Poly(oxyethylene) alkyl ether (alkyl C=12-15)
Rationale for classification: Based on the rat LC50 (inhalation route) value of 1.5mg/L (alkyl C12-13, EO6) (4 hours).

Name: Coal tar naphtha
Rationale for classification: Category 5 because of SPECIES: Rat; ENDPOINT: LC50 (4-8h) VALUE: 5.3mg/L (EHC20, 1982)
